metadata./Title: Atypical Cogan syndrome: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Cogan syndrome is a rare autoimmune systemic vasculitis presenting with interstitial keratitis and audiovestibular symptoms. The atypical form, characterized by more extensive ocular lesions with audiovestibular 
symptoms appearing with a longer delay and more frequent systemic features, is usually underdiagnosed, delaying 
treatment.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We report the case of a 30-year-old Mediterranean female who presented recurrent left red 
and painful eye. The evolution in flare-ups during 3 years, associated with a nonspecific biological inflammatory 
response, motivated ocular biopsies demonstrating diffuse inflammatory changes from the cornea to the sclera. Since 
Morocco is an endemic region for tuberculosis, the laboratory tests were expanded to identify the latent forms based 
on the tuberculin skin test and QuantiFERON TB Gold in tube assay, both positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis 
infection. Thus, antibacillary chemotherapy was started for 6 months, with reappearance of the symptoms at the end 
of treatment. Three years later, the patient presented isolated and fluctuating audiovestibular Ménière-like symptoms, 
with progressive sensorineural hearing loss. The nonstabilization under usual medical treatment along with her diffuse inflammatory ocular lesions led to the diagnosis of atypical Cogan syndrome. The patient received long-term 
corticosteroid with notable improvement.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Cogan syndrome is a rare autoimmune disease that should be considered when faced with ocular and audiovestibular manifestations, even in its atypical form, to provide early and adequate treatment, which 
is the main prognosis factor in the control of irreversible lesions. Thus, interdisciplinary collaboration is fundamental 
along with screening for other infectious and systemic disorders that should include tuberculosis.
Keywords  Cogan syndrome, Keratitis, Audiovestibular dysfunction, Tuberculosis, Corticosteroids
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Cogan syndrome (CS) is a rare autoimmune systemic 
vasculitis presenting with interstitial keratitis and audi ovestibular symptoms. It remains a diagnosis of exclu sion after ruling out systemic and infectious diseases. The 
atypical form, characterized by more extensive ocular 
lesions with audiovestibular symptoms appearing with a longer delay of more than 2 years and more frequent sys temic features, is usually underdiagnosed [1].
The treatment is based on corticosteroids and immu nomodulatory therapy, with promising prognosis, par ticularly with an early start that can improve the odds of 
recovering hearing loss [2].
Case presentation
We report the case of a 30-year-old Mediterranean 
female, with no medical history, who presented recurrent 
left red and painful eye with tearing and photophobia 
evolving in flare-ups during 3 years. Slit-lamp examina tion showed stromal keratitis with scleral edema and ten derness along with dilation of the deep episcleral vessels.Open Access

To recognize any associated systemic disorders, tar geted laboratory tests were carried out, summarized 
as follows (Table  1): besides positive antinuclear anti bodies (Anti-Jo1) and a slight nonspecific inflamma tory response with C-reactive protein (CRP) elevated to 
36.39  mg/ml, the laboratory tests were negative. Also, 
ocular magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) returned nor mal with no scleral thickening or enhancement or focal 
cellulitis. Histopathologic examination of corneal and 
scleral tissues biopsies demonstrated diffuse inflamma tory changes with lymphocyte infiltration, fibrosis, and 
vascular occlusions from the cornea to the sclera.
Since Morocco is an endemic region for tuberculosis 
(TB), the laboratory tests were expanded to identify the 
latent forms based on the tuberculin skin test (TST) and 
QuantiFERON TB Gold in tube assay (QFT-GIT), both 
positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Thus, 
antibacillary chemotherapy (rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazi namide, and ethambutol) was started for 6 months, with 
reappearance of the symptoms at the end of treatment.
Three years later, the patient presented isolated and 
recurrent audiovestibular symptoms with Ménière-like 
spontaneous vertigo attacks (with left canal deficit in 
the caloric test at 47%) with left fluctuating and progres sive sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus, refractory 
to usual medical treatment based on betahistine (24 mg 
twice a day) and thiazide diuretics (Fig. 1).
The nonstabilization of the patient under Ménière’s 
medical treatment, along with her diffuse inflamma tory ocular lesions from the cornea to the sclera, led to 
the diagnosis of atypical Cogan syndrome. The patient 
received long-term corticosteroid (oral prednisone of 1 
mg/kg/day) but refused immunosuppressive therapies. 
The overall evolution was marked by notable improve ment with optimal visual prognosis with no long-term ocular symptoms nor vertigo attacks, however 40 dB 
hearing loss remained.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Cogan syndrome (CS) is a rare autoimmune disease that 
has been considered as a primary variable vessel vasculi tis and characterized by inflammatory response of the eye 
and the audiovestibular system, with possible systemic 
involvement [1, 2]. In 1934, it was described by Baum gartner and Morgan as a nonsyphilitic interstitial kera titis with vestibular dysfunction resembling Ménière’s 
syndrome [3]. Later, in 1945, it was defined as a proper 
clinical entity by David Cogan after describing a series of 
four patients [4]. Even if CS can appear at any age, the 
most frequently affected population is young adults (30–
40 years), with no gender predominance [1, 2].
The pathogenesis of CS is still unknown. It was first 
related to Chlamydia psittaci  infection regarding the 
high titers of antibodies to Chlamydia trachomatis and 
the previous infection signs reported in a few patients [1, 
5]. However, the effective role of Chlamydia  or any other 
infectious agent was never truly established, and it is now 
considered to be an autoimmune disorder with humoral 
and cellular immune responses leading to the expression 
and upregulation of cytokines such as intercellular cell 
adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) and interleukin (IL)-1β, 
but with no particular biomarker [1, 5], until 2002, when 
a specific antibody associated with the pathogenesis 
of CS was demonstrated: an immunoglobulin G anti body against DEP-1/CD148 autoantigen on endothelial 
and supporting cells of the sensory nerve epithelium of 
the inner ear [6]. In 2023, Chen et al. described bilateral 
atypical CS with a positive polymerase chain reaction 
(PCR) test for severe acute respiratory syndrome coro navirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) RNA, reporting a triggering link 
between coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) infection 
and systemic vasculitis, possibly explained by the fact 
that SARS-CoV-2 may increase angiotensin II, decrease 
nitric oxide production in addition to the  immune dys regulation and autoantibody reactions, resulting in vaso constriction and endothelial damage, ultimately leading 
to vasculitis [7].
The histopathological examination of corneal and 
cochlear tissues shows chronic inflammatory process 
with plasma cells and lymphocyte infiltration and pos sible cochlear neuron loss, endolymphatic hydrops, new 
bone formation, degenerative changes in the organ of 
Corti, and atrophy of vestibulocochlear cranial nerve [1], 
as found in our patient.
In 1980, Haynes et al. [8] classified CS into two forms: 
the typical form, originally defined by Cogan as a non syphilitic interstitial keratitis rapidly progressing then 
resolving, with possible recurrences, associated with Table 1 Common laboratory tests to rule out systemic or

audiovestibular symptoms occurring within 2  years, 
usually leading to rapidly aggravating deafness; and the 
atypical form, in which more extended ocular lesions are 
present with audiovestibular dysfunction appearing with 
a longer delay and more frequent systemic features. Nev ertheless, the typical form may develop to the atypical 
one later [1].
CS remains a diagnosis of exclusion that needs to rule 
out infectious and systemic diseases, including syphilis 
[1]. In our context, since tuberculosis is a major health 
problem in Morocco with an incidence of 82 per 100,000 
people in 2022 according to the World Bank collection 
of development indicators, we can suppose that it can be 
associated with CS or at least is a differential diagnosis 
that needs to be explored and ruled out. Its diagnosis can 
be challenging specifically because of the paucibacillary 
nature of the disease and lack of laboratory facilities in 
resource-limited settings [9].
Management of CS depends on the severity of the dis ease and the involved organs [2]. The standard of care 
includes glucocorticoids and immunosuppressive medi cations, but no standard treatment plan has been estab lished [10].
The topical form of steroids can be used for mild ocu lar symptoms [2]. The response on corticosteroids alone 
is up to 84% according to a study on 62 patients. Over all, the visual prognosis remains excellent with only 3% 
of long-term ocular symptoms [11]. On the other hand, 
it is observed that early and high-dose steroids (IV glu cocorticoid or oral prednisone of at least 1 mg/kg/day 
or intratympanic injection as adjunct therapy) improve 
the odds of recovering hearing loss when given within 
2 weeks of initial auditory symptoms. However, auditory 
symptoms still have a poor prognosis in the long term 
since the hearing loss is irreversible [1, 2].
Immunosuppressive therapies are considered in cases 
of nonresponse, intolerance, or contraindication to 
steroids. The molecules used in that indication are var ious, including cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, cyclo sporine, mycophenolate mofetil, and azathioprine [2].
Also, the use of biologics in CS therapy is rising, 
including infliximab, rituximab, and tocilizumab (TCZ), 
proposing novel remedies for these patients. Indeed, 
infliximab is becoming a potential first-line treatment 
in association with corticosteroids, while studies have 
reported successful stabilization of CS hearing impair ment with TCZ after successive failures of glucocorticoid, 
cellular immunosuppressant, and infliximab therapy [2, 
10].
The aim of treatment remains the preservation of 
as much hearing and vestibular function as possi ble, avoiding ocular and systemic complications from 
vasculitis [2 ]. However, despite medical treatment, auditory prognosis still uncertain, with irreversible 
severe to profound hearing loss in 50–60% of patients 
who become candidates for cochlear implantation [12].
Boumghit et al. [ 12] reported 10 patients with CS 
operated for 14 cochlear implants between 2005 and 
2020 with significant improvement in speech reception 
threshold and maximum intelligibility (P  = 0.0002) after 
1 year of followup, in line with
sections.Results:
results reported in lit erature of 82.5–94% of mean word recognition scores 
at a mean 1–9 years of follow-up. Indeed, literature 
data report good functional outcomes as long as the 
electrode array is properly inserted. However, adequate 
preimplant counseling is mandatory, to adjust patient 
expectations and evaluate the necessity for bilateral 
implantation [13].
Thus, cochlear implant should be considered in 
severe to profound hearing loss resistant to medical 
treatment, with no delay regarding the threat of coch lear fibrosis [12]. But, even with a cochlear implant, 
results may deteriorate owing to progressive cochlear 
ossification with worsening of speech perception abili ties [13]. Also, Bovo et al. [ 13] reported a case with 
decreased speech perception ability to identification of 
words in closed set probably owing to auditory dyssyn chrony, as an atypical consequence of the syndrome.
Conclusion
Cogan syndrome is a rare autoimmune disease that 
should be considered when faced with ocular and audi ovestibular manifestations, even in its atypical form, 
to provide early and adequate treatment, which is the 
main prognosis factor in the control of irreversible 
lesions. Thus, interdisciplinary collaboration is funda mental as well as screening for other infectious and sys temic disorders that should include tuberculosis.
